passages.title: University Accommodation Office
passages.content: Good morning, I'm calling from the university accommodation office. I understand you've applied for on-campus housing for the upcoming semester. Let me go through your application details. You've requested a single room in the graduate student residence, which is located in the North Campus area. The monthly rent is £650, which includes utilities and internet access. The building has 24-hour security, laundry facilities on each floor, and a common kitchen area. The contract period is from September 1st to May 31st, with a £200 security deposit required. Payment is due on the 1st of each month. There's also a £50 application fee that needs to be paid within the next week to secure your place. The building is within walking distance of the main library and the student union, and there's a shuttle bus service that runs every 15 minutes during peak hours.

passages.title: Environmental Science Lecture
passages.content: Today we'll be discussing the impact of climate change on marine ecosystems. Recent studies have shown that ocean temperatures have increased by approximately 0.8 degrees Celsius over the past century. This seemingly small change has had profound effects on marine life. Coral reefs, which are particularly sensitive to temperature changes, have experienced widespread bleaching events. In fact, over 50% of the Great Barrier Reef has been affected by bleaching since 2016. Additionally, rising sea levels, which have increased by about 20 centimeters globally, are threatening coastal habitats. The acidification of oceans due to increased carbon dioxide absorption is also affecting shellfish and other marine organisms. Scientists predict that if current trends continue, we could see a further temperature increase of 2-4 degrees Celsius by the end of this century.

passages.title: Job Interview Preparation
passages.content: Welcome to today's workshop on job interview preparation. First, let's discuss the importance of research. You should thoroughly research the company, including its history, values, and recent developments. This shows genuine interest and helps you ask intelligent questions. Next, prepare your responses to common questions like 'Tell me about yourself' and 'Why do you want this position?' Practice these answers out loud, but avoid memorizing them word for word. During the interview, maintain good eye contact and use confident body language. Remember to bring extra copies of your resume and a list of references. Follow up with a thank-you email within 24 hours of the interview. This demonstrates professionalism and keeps you fresh in the interviewer's mind.

passages.title: Sustainable Energy Solutions
passages.content: Today's lecture focuses on sustainable energy solutions for urban areas. Solar panels have become increasingly efficient, with modern systems converting up to 22% of sunlight into electricity. Wind turbines, particularly offshore installations, can generate substantial power with minimal environmental impact. Geothermal energy, which harnesses heat from the Earth's core, provides consistent power regardless of weather conditions. However, the initial installation costs remain high, often requiring government subsidies to be economically viable. Battery storage technology has improved significantly, with lithium-ion batteries now capable of storing energy for extended periods. This addresses the intermittent nature of renewable energy sources. Smart grid systems help distribute power more efficiently and reduce waste.

passages.title: Healthcare System Reform
passages.content: The government has announced comprehensive reforms to the healthcare system. The new policy will be implemented over a three-year period, starting from January next year. The reforms include increasing the number of general practitioners by 15%, reducing waiting times for specialist appointments to a maximum of four weeks, and introducing a new digital health record system. The total budget allocated for these reforms is £2.3 billion, with £800 million dedicated to infrastructure improvements. The policy also includes mandatory health insurance for all citizens, with premiums based on income levels. Employers will be required to contribute 60% of their employees' insurance costs. The reforms aim to reduce overall healthcare costs by 12% within five years while improving patient outcomes.

passages.title: International Trade Agreement
passages.content: Representatives from 15 countries have signed a new international trade agreement that will eliminate tariffs on 95% of goods traded between member nations. The agreement, which took five years to negotiate, will come into effect on March 1st of next year. It includes provisions for intellectual property protection, environmental standards, and labor rights. The agreement is expected to increase trade volume by approximately 18% within the first three years. Member countries represent 40% of global GDP and include major economies such as the United States, Japan, and Germany. The agreement also establishes a dispute resolution mechanism and requires regular reviews every two years. Environmental provisions require all member countries to reduce carbon emissions by 25% by 2030.

passages.title: Urban Planning and Green Spaces
passages.content: Today's lecture focuses on the importance of green spaces in urban planning. Research has shown that access to parks and green areas can reduce stress levels by up to 30% and improve overall mental health. Cities with more green spaces typically have lower crime rates and higher property values. The World Health Organization recommends that urban residents should have access to at least 9 square meters of green space per person. However, many cities fall short of this target. London, for example, has approximately 7 square meters per person, while New York has only 5 square meters. Innovative solutions include rooftop gardens, vertical forests, and converting abandoned lots into community gardens. These projects not only provide environmental benefits but also create social spaces that strengthen community bonds.

passages.title: Digital Privacy and Data Protection
passages.content: The topic of digital privacy has become increasingly important in our connected world. Recent surveys indicate that 78% of internet users are concerned about their online privacy, yet only 23% regularly read privacy policies. The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation, implemented in 2018, has set new standards for data protection worldwide. Companies that violate these regulations can face fines of up to 4% of their global annual revenue. The regulation gives users the right to access their personal data, request corrections, and demand deletion of their information. However, enforcement remains challenging, with only 40% of companies fully compliant with the requirements. Experts suggest that individuals should use strong passwords, enable two-factor authentication, and regularly review their privacy settings to protect their digital footprint.

passages.title: Remote Work and Productivity
passages.content: The shift to remote work has fundamentally changed how organizations operate. Studies conducted during the pandemic showed that 65% of employees reported higher productivity when working from home, while 35% experienced challenges with work-life balance. Companies that implemented remote work policies saw a 22% reduction in operational costs, primarily due to decreased office space requirements. However, the transition also revealed significant challenges, including difficulties in maintaining team cohesion and ensuring equal access to opportunities. Organizations that successfully adapted to remote work invested heavily in digital collaboration tools and established clear communication protocols. The hybrid work model, combining office and remote work, has emerged as the preferred approach for 70% of companies surveyed.

passages.title: Sustainable Transportation Solutions
passages.content: Cities worldwide are implementing sustainable transportation solutions to reduce carbon emissions and improve air quality. Electric vehicle adoption has increased by 40% annually over the past five years, with Norway leading the way with 75% of new car sales being electric. Public transportation systems are being modernized with electric buses and trains, while cycling infrastructure has expanded significantly. Amsterdam, for example, now has over 400 kilometers of dedicated cycling lanes. Car-sharing programs have reduced private vehicle ownership by 15% in participating cities. The integration of smart technology, including real-time tracking and mobile payment systems, has improved the efficiency and convenience of public transport. These initiatives have resulted in a 25% reduction in urban carbon emissions in cities that have implemented comprehensive sustainable transport policies.

passages.title: The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on Employment
passages.content: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) technology has sparked intense debate about its potential impact on employment patterns across various industries. While some experts predict widespread job displacement, others argue that AI will create new opportunities and enhance human productivity rather than replace workers entirely. Research conducted by the McKinsey Global Institute suggests that by 2030, up to 375 million workers worldwide may need to switch occupational categories due to automation. However, this same study indicates that AI could also create 65 million new jobs that don't currently exist. The key factor determining whether AI leads to job creation or destruction appears to be the nature of the tasks involved. Routine, repetitive tasks are most susceptible to automation, while jobs requiring creativity, emotional intelligence, and complex problem-solving are likely to remain predominantly human domains. Furthermore, historical evidence suggests that technological revolutions typically result in net job creation over the long term, despite initial disruption. The Industrial Revolution, for instance, initially caused significant unemployment but ultimately led to unprecedented economic growth and job creation. The challenge for policymakers and educators lies in preparing workers for the transition, ensuring that education systems adapt to equip people with the skills needed in an AI-driven economy.

passages.title: The Psychology of Consumer Behavior in Digital Marketing
passages.content: Digital marketing has fundamentally transformed how businesses understand and influence consumer behavior. The advent of big data analytics has enabled marketers to track consumer interactions with unprecedented precision, revealing patterns that were previously invisible. One of the most significant findings in this field is the concept of 'choice paralysis,' where consumers become overwhelmed by too many options and either delay decisions or choose not to purchase at all. Research by psychologists Sheena Iyengar and Mark Lepper demonstrated that when consumers were presented with 24 varieties of jam instead of 6, they were ten times less likely to make a purchase. This phenomenon has profound implications for e-commerce platforms and digital marketing strategies. Another critical insight involves the role of social proof in online purchasing decisions. Studies show that products with customer reviews, ratings, and testimonials experience significantly higher conversion rates than those without. The mere presence of social proof can increase sales by up to 270%, according to research published in the Journal of Consumer Research. Furthermore, the timing of marketing messages has emerged as a crucial factor in consumer engagement. Analysis of email marketing campaigns reveals that personalized messages sent at optimal times can achieve open rates 26% higher than generic messages sent at random times. The psychological principle of reciprocity also plays a vital role in digital marketing success. When businesses provide value through free content, samples, or services, consumers feel compelled to reciprocate, often through purchases or brand loyalty.

passages.title: The Future of Renewable Energy
passages.content: The global transition to renewable energy sources represents one of the most significant technological and economic shifts of the 21st century. Solar photovoltaic technology has seen remarkable cost reductions, with prices falling by approximately 90% over the past decade. This dramatic decrease has made solar energy competitive with traditional fossil fuels in many markets. Wind energy has also experienced substantial growth, with offshore wind farms becoming increasingly viable due to technological advancements. The International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) estimates that renewable energy could create up to 28 million jobs globally by 2050, significantly more than the fossil fuel industry currently employs. Battery storage technology has been a crucial enabler of renewable energy adoption, with costs decreasing by 85% since 2010. This has allowed for better integration of intermittent renewable sources into the electrical grid. However, the transition presents challenges, particularly in energy storage and grid infrastructure. Countries with ambitious renewable energy targets, such as Denmark and Germany, have demonstrated that with proper planning and investment, renewable energy can provide a substantial portion of national electricity needs. The economic benefits extend beyond environmental considerations, with renewable energy projects often creating local employment opportunities and reducing energy import dependence.

passages.title: The Impact of Social Media on Mental Health
passages.content: The relationship between social media use and mental health has become a subject of intense research and public debate. Studies have revealed complex and often contradictory findings regarding the psychological effects of social media platforms. Research published in the Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology found that limiting social media use to 30 minutes per day resulted in significant reductions in loneliness and depression among participants. However, other studies suggest that the impact varies significantly based on how individuals use these platforms. Active engagement, such as creating content and meaningful interactions, appears to have more positive effects than passive consumption of others' posts. The phenomenon of 'social comparison' has been identified as a key factor in negative mental health outcomes, with users often comparing their lives to carefully curated online representations. Adolescents appear particularly vulnerable to these effects, with research indicating that heavy social media use during teenage years correlates with increased rates of anxiety and depression. However, social media also provides important benefits, including social support networks, educational opportunities, and platforms for self-expression. The challenge lies in developing healthier usage patterns and digital literacy skills that enable users to navigate these platforms mindfully.

passages.title: The Evolution of Remote Work
passages.content: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the adoption of remote work practices that had been gradually emerging over the previous decade. Organizations worldwide were forced to rapidly implement work-from-home policies, leading to unprecedented changes in workplace dynamics. Research conducted by Stanford University found that remote workers were 13% more productive than their office-based counterparts, primarily due to reduced commuting time and fewer workplace distractions. However, the transition also revealed significant challenges, including difficulties in maintaining team cohesion and ensuring equal access to opportunities for career advancement. Companies that successfully adapted to remote work invested heavily in digital collaboration tools and established clear communication protocols. The hybrid work model, combining office and remote work, has emerged as the preferred approach for many organizations. This model offers flexibility while maintaining opportunities for face-to-face collaboration and team building. The shift has also led to changes in urban planning, with some cities experiencing population redistribution as workers move away from expensive urban centers. Additionally, the remote work trend has created new opportunities for digital nomads and international employment, with some countries introducing special visas to attract remote workers. The long-term implications for office real estate, urban development, and work-life balance continue to evolve as organizations refine their remote work strategies.

passages.title: The Science of Sleep and Productivity
passages.content: Sleep science has revealed the critical importance of adequate rest for cognitive function, emotional regulation, and overall productivity. Research indicates that sleep deprivation can impair decision-making abilities, reduce creativity, and increase the likelihood of errors in the workplace. The National Sleep Foundation recommends 7-9 hours of sleep per night for adults, with teenagers requiring 8-10 hours for optimal functioning. Sleep occurs in cycles of approximately 90 minutes each, with REM (rapid eye movement) sleep accounting for about 25% of total sleep time. This stage is crucial for memory consolidation and learning. Studies have shown that individuals who consistently get less than 6 hours of sleep per night experience significant declines in cognitive performance, with reaction times increasing by up to 50% after 24 hours without sleep. The relationship between sleep and productivity extends beyond individual performance to organizational outcomes. Companies that implement policies supporting healthy sleep habits, such as flexible work schedules and nap rooms, report higher employee satisfaction and reduced absenteeism. The economic cost of sleep deprivation is substantial, with estimates suggesting that insufficient sleep costs the global economy over $400 billion annually in lost productivity. Understanding the science of sleep has led to the development of various interventions, including cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia and workplace wellness programs that prioritize sleep hygiene.

passages.title: The Human Digestive System
passages.content: The human digestive system is a complex network of organs responsible for breaking down food and absorbing nutrients. The process begins in the mouth, where mechanical and chemical digestion starts with chewing and the action of salivary enzymes. Food then travels through the esophagus to the stomach, where gastric juices containing hydrochloric acid and pepsin break down proteins. The small intestine, which is approximately 6 meters long, is where most nutrient absorption occurs through specialized structures called villi. The large intestine, or colon, absorbs water and electrolytes while housing beneficial bacteria that aid in digestion. The liver produces bile, which is stored in the gallbladder and released to help digest fats. The pancreas secretes digestive enzymes and hormones that regulate blood sugar levels. Finally, waste products are eliminated through the rectum and anus.

passages.title: The Psychology of Decision Making
passages.content: Human decision-making processes are influenced by various cognitive biases and heuristics that can lead to systematic errors in judgment. The availability heuristic, first identified by psychologists Amos Tversky and Daniel Kahneman, causes people to overestimate the probability of events that are easily recalled from memory. For example, people often overestimate the likelihood of plane crashes because these events receive extensive media coverage, despite being statistically rare. Another common bias is the confirmation bias, where individuals seek out information that confirms their existing beliefs while ignoring contradictory evidence. This bias is particularly evident in political and social media contexts, where people tend to consume content that aligns with their viewpoints. The anchoring effect occurs when people rely too heavily on the first piece of information they receive when making decisions. Research shows that even arbitrary numbers can serve as anchors, significantly influencing subsequent judgments. Understanding these biases is crucial for improving decision-making quality in both personal and professional contexts.

passages.title: The History of Computer Programming Languages
passages.content: The evolution of computer programming languages reflects the changing needs and capabilities of computing technology. The first high-level programming language, FORTRAN, was developed by IBM in the 1950s to simplify scientific calculations. COBOL, created in 1959, became the standard for business applications and is still used in many financial systems today. The 1970s saw the development of C, which became the foundation for many modern programming languages including C++, Java, and Python. Object-oriented programming, introduced with Simula in the 1960s, revolutionized software development by allowing programmers to create reusable code components. The rise of the internet in the 1990s led to the development of web-specific languages such as JavaScript and PHP. More recently, the emergence of artificial intelligence and machine learning has driven the popularity of languages like Python and R, which offer extensive libraries for data analysis and statistical computing.

part2.name: Part 2: Individual Long Turn
part2.description: Speak for 2 minutes on a given topic

questions.question_text: Describe a place you would like to visit in the future. You should say: where it is, why you want to go there, what you would do there, and explain why this place interests you.
Talk about a book you have read recently. You should say: what the book is about, when you read it, why you chose to read it, and explain what you learned from it.
Describe a person who has influenced you in your life. You should say: who this person is, how you know them, what they have done to influence you, and explain why they have been important to you.
Talk about an important event in your life. You should say: what the event was, when it happened, why it was important, and explain how it affected your life.
Describe your hometown. You should say: where it is located, what it is famous for, what you like about it, and explain whether you would recommend others to visit it.
Talk about a skill you would like to learn. You should say: what the skill is, why you want to learn it, how you would learn it, and explain how it would be useful to you.
Describe a memorable journey you have taken. You should say: where you went, when you went there, who you went with, and explain why it was memorable.
Talk about a piece of technology you use regularly. You should say: what it is, how often you use it, what you use it for, and explain why it is important to you.
Describe a restaurant you enjoy going to. You should say: where it is located, what type of food it serves, how often you go there, and explain why you like it.
Talk about a goal you have achieved. You should say: what the goal was, when you achieved it, how you achieved it, and explain how you felt when you accomplished it.
Describe a person you admire. You should say: who this person is, what they do, why you admire them, and explain what qualities they have that you find impressive.
Talk about a time when you helped someone. You should say: who you helped, what you did to help them, why they needed help, and explain how you felt about helping them.
Describe a place where you like to study or work. You should say: where this place is, what it looks like, when you go there, and explain why you prefer this place.
Talk about a tradition in your country. You should say: what the tradition is, when it is celebrated, how people celebrate it, and explain why it is important to your culture.
Describe a time when you were surprised. You should say: what happened, when it happened, who was involved, and explain why you were surprised.
What are the advantages and disadvantages of living in a big city compared to a small town?
How has technology changed the way people communicate in recent years?
Do you think education should be free for everyone? Why or why not?
What are the benefits of learning a foreign language? How important is it in today's world?
How important is it to protect the environment? What can individuals do to help?
What are the pros and cons of working from home versus working in an office?
How has social media affected relationships between people?
Do you think it's better to live in the past or focus on the future? Why?
What role does advertising play in our daily lives? Is it mostly positive or negative?
How has the way people shop changed in recent years? What do you think about online shopping?
What are the challenges of raising children in today's society?
How important is it to maintain traditional customs and values in a modern world?
What are the benefits and drawbacks of globalization?
How has the role of women in society changed over the past few decades?
What do you think about the increasing use of artificial intelligence in our daily lives?
How important is it to have a work-life balance? What are the challenges in achieving this?
What are the advantages and disadvantages of living in a multicultural society?
How has the way people travel changed over the years? What do you think about budget travel?
What role does the media play in shaping public opinion? Is this positive or negative?
How important is it to preserve historical buildings and monuments?
What are the challenges of maintaining good health in modern society?
How has the way people entertain themselves changed over the years?
What do you think about the increasing focus on mental health awareness?
How important is it to have good communication skills in today's world?
What are the benefits and challenges of living in a digital age?
How has the way people learn changed with the introduction of technology?
What role does creativity play in solving problems in modern society?
How important is it to have a sense of community in today's world?
What are the challenges of maintaining privacy in the digital age?

You recently stayed at a hotel and experienced several problems during your stay. Write a letter to the hotel manager describing the issues you encountered and what you would like them to do about it.

You are planning to move to a new city for work and need to find suitable accommodation. Write a letter to a local real estate agent asking for information about available apartments in your budget range.

You have been invited to a close friend's wedding but cannot attend due to unavoidable circumstances. Write a letter to your friend explaining why you cannot come and expressing your best wishes for their special day.

You recently purchased an expensive electronic device online, but it arrived damaged and is not functioning properly. Write a letter to the customer service department requesting a replacement or full refund.
You want to apply for a job in another city and need help with finding accommodation and information about the area. Write a letter to a friend who lives there asking for assistance.

You recently attended a conference at a local venue and were very impressed with the facilities and service. Write a letter to the venue manager expressing your satisfaction and recommending improvements for future events.
You have been offered a job in another country and need to apply for a work visa. Write a letter to the embassy requesting information about the application process and required documents.
You recently joined a gym but are not satisfied with the facilities and services provided. Write a letter to the gym manager explaining your concerns and what changes you would like to see.
You are planning a family vacation and want to book a holiday package. Write a letter to a travel agency asking for information about available packages, prices, and booking procedures.
You have been living in your current apartment for two years and the lease is about to expire. Write a letter to your landlord requesting a renewal of the lease and discussing any necessary repairs.
You recently attended a restaurant with friends and had an excellent dining experience. Write a letter to the restaurant manager complimenting the staff and food quality.
You are interested in enrolling in a language course at a local institute. Write a letter to the institute asking for information about course schedules, fees, and enrollment procedures.
You have been experiencing problems with your internet service provider for the past month. Write a letter to the company explaining the issues and requesting immediate resolution.
You are planning to organize a charity event and need to book a community hall. Write a letter to the hall manager requesting information about availability, rental fees, and facilities.
You recently visited a museum and were disappointed with the exhibits and services. Write a letter to the museum director expressing your concerns and suggesting improvements.

Some people believe that the government should invest more money in public transportation, while others think that individuals should be responsible for their own transportation. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
Many people believe that the best way to learn a foreign language is to live in the country where it is spoken. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
Some people think that the government should spend money on public services rather than on the arts. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this view?
In many countries, people are living longer than ever before. What are the advantages and disadvantages of this trend for individuals and society?
Some people believe that children should be taught to be competitive, while others think they should be taught to cooperate. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing use of technology in education has both positive and negative effects. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
Some people believe that it is better to live in a big city, while others prefer to live in the countryside. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
Many people believe that the internet has made communication easier and more convenient, while others think it has made people more isolated. Discuss both views and give your opinion.

Some people think that the government should provide free healthcare for all citizens, while others believe that individuals should pay for their own medical treatment. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing popularity of online shopping has affected traditional retail businesses. What are the advantages and disadvantages of this trend?
Some people believe that schools should focus more on practical skills rather than academic subjects. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
Many people believe that the media has too much influence on people's lives today. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
Some people think that it is better to work for a large company, while others prefer to work for a small company. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing use of social media has changed the way people interact with each other. What are the positive and negative effects of this change?
Some people believe that it is important to preserve traditional customs and values, while others think that society should be more modern and flexible. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
Many people believe that the best way to solve environmental problems is to increase the cost of fuel for cars and other vehicles. To what extent do you agree or disagree?

Some people think that universities should provide graduates with the knowledge and skills needed in the workplace. Others think that the true function of a university should be to give access to knowledge for its own sake. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing number of people living in cities has created many problems. What are the main problems faced by people living in cities, and how can these problems be solved?
Some people believe that it is better to travel alone, while others think it is better to travel with a group. Discuss both views and give your opinion.

Many people believe that the best way to reduce crime is to give longer prison sentences. Others believe that there are better alternative ways to reduce crime. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
Some people think that the government should provide free housing for everyone who cannot afford it. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
The increasing use of artificial intelligence in various fields has both benefits and drawbacks. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
Some people believe that it is better to work from home, while others think it is better to work in an office. Discuss both views and give your opinion.

Many people believe that the best way to improve public health is to increase the number of sports facilities. Others think that this would have little effect on public health. Discuss both views and give your opinion.

Some people think that the government should spend money on exploring outer space, while others believe that it is more important to spend money on solving problems on Earth. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing use of mobile phones and computers has made communication easier, but it has also led to people spending less time together. To what extent do you agree or disagree?
Some people believe that it is better to live in a house, while others think it is better to live in an apartment. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
Many people believe that the best way to learn about other cultures is to travel to different countries. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
Some people think that the government should provide free education at all levels, while others believe that individuals should pay for their own education. Discuss both views and give your opinion.
The increasing use of renewable energy sources has both advantages and disadvantages. To what extent do you agree or disagree with this statement?
